1606864324_1HK2gCWJmrTvacZbHqEC27oVygDjU.body:
It will let you go over the limit, but it will start deleting optional storage content until the total consumed space is less than the configured limit.  I had a really hard time figuring out why the system would work so hard to download new content, only to turn around a bit later and delete a bunch of the content. 
I had to increase the optional_limit to make that number larger so that I could hold more content.  It defaults to only allowing 10% of space on the drive for optional files. (an absurdly low limit if you're trying to build a full copy of large zites.)  The config option (measured in gigabytes):     optional_limit = 768

1607610507_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRF.body:
This was actually a worthwhile tangent.  I've spent a some time checking out Aether over the last couple of days and I'm pretty impressed with the technology.  The guy who designed it is a goddamn genius.  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A9zL2csO7t8  Worth your time to watch and learn, this guy has some really different creative solutions to distributed networking problems and has created some very cool shit. 

I was a bit disheartened to see that Aether, much like most p2p networks, is a ghost town and the guy who designed it seems to be growing tired.    I'm still going to hang around, though.

Thanks for the link, @styromaniac
